title: Building Accessible Web Components
excerpt: Best practices for creating web components that work for everyone, including keyboard navigation and screen readers.
content:
Accessibility isn't just a nice-to-have—it's essential for creating inclusive web experiences. ## Why Accessibility Matters Over 1 billion people worldwide have some form of disability. Building accessible components ensures everyone can use your application. ## Key Principles ### 1. Semantic HTML Always use the right HTML element for the job: ```html
Submit
``` ### 2. Keyboard Navigation Ensure all interactive elements are keyboard accessible: - Use `tabindex` appropriately - Handle `keydown` events for custom components - Provide visible focus indicators ### 3. ARIA Attributes Use ARIA when native HTML isn't sufficient: ```html ``` ### 4. Color Contrast Maintain a minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for normal text. ## Testing Use tools like axe DevTools or Lighthouse to audit your components.

title: My Journey from JavaScript to TypeScript
excerpt: How switching to TypeScript improved my code quality and developer experience.
content:
When I first heard about TypeScript, I was skeptical. Why add complexity to JavaScript?

## The Turning Point

After spending hours debugging a production issue caused by a typo in a property name, I decided to give TypeScript a try.

## What I Learned

### Types Catch Bugs Early

```typescript
interface User {
  name: string;
  email: string;
}

function greetUser(user: User) {
  // TypeScript catches this typo!
  console.log(`Hello, ${user.naem}`); // Error: Property 'naem' does not exist
}
```

### Better IDE Support

Autocompletion, refactoring, and go-to-definition work much better with TypeScript.

### Self-Documenting Code

Types serve as documentation that stays in sync with your code.

## Tips for Getting Started

1. Start with `strict: false` and gradually enable strict checks
2. Use `unknown` instead of `any` when the type is uncertain
3. Leverage type inference—don't over-annotate

## Conclusion

TypeScript has made me a more productive developer. The initial learning curve is worth the long-term benefits.
